hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
gpt-4_1-nano_translation: A ship dispatched by 'Ama'u the chief from Waikīkī arrived, with four warriors. On the same boat were about thirty-eight men, making a total of forty-four people. When they reached the school of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was present. They prepared to leave, when Nāmakaokapāo'o called from the head of the group. Hearing a voice, but not seeing anyone's body, they asked: "Where are you, who is calling out?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "Here I am, up here." Suddenly, eight men climbed up—four on each side of the house, with Nāmakaokapāo'o found in the middle. They asked: "What are you calling us for?" The men answered: "We come to fight with Nāmakaokapāo'o, that small boy like yourself, who is strong and brave, the one who killed his father, Puali'i."
gpt-4_1-nano_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
A ship dispatched by 'Ama'u the chief from Waikīkī arrived, with four warriors. On the same boat were about thirty-eight men, making a total of forty-four people. When they reached the school of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was present. They prepared to leave, when Nāmakaokapāo'o called from the head of the group. Hearing a voice, but not seeing anyone's body, they asked: "Where are you, who is calling out?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "Here I am, up here." Suddenly, eight men climbed up—four on each side of the house, with Nāmakaokapāo'o found in the middle. They asked: "What are you calling us for?" The men answered: "We come to fight with Nāmakaokapāo'o, that small boy like yourself, who is strong and brave, the one who killed his father, Puali'i."
</translation>

<commentary>
• Paragraph 12 functions as a critical moment of encounter and confrontation, where a group of warriors arrive at Keahumoa, a significant location, likely a battlefield or strategic site, reminiscent of traditional martial narratives in Hawaiian history.
• The arrival of four men (po'e kaua) with about thirty-eight additional men, totaling forty-four, signals a notable gathering—numbers significant in Hawaiian cultural contexts, often representing collective strength or the importance of unity in warfare.
• The scene opens with a dispatch from 'Ama'u, a chiefly figure from Waikīkī, indicating a connection to high-ranking lineages and possibly a mission or military mobilization—common themes in Hawaiian history of chiefly warfare and alliances.
• "Keahumoa" is a significant place name, likely a strategic or sacred site in the narrative, perhaps associated with a legendary event or battle.
• The act of entering the house with no one present may symbolize an initial phase of reconnaissance or supernatural intervention, a common motif in Hawaiian legends involving spirits or ancestral spirits.  
• Nāmakaokapāo'o's call from the 'luna' (upper) position, without revealing his body, hints at his spiritual or supernatural presence, aligning with the Hawaiian tradition of *kāne or akua* acting from unseen or elevated realms.
• The question of "Where are you?" and the response highlight the supernatural or spiritual nature of Nāmakaokapāo'o—he might be a guardian, spirit, or deity—playing a role akin to a protector or challenger.
• The eight warriors ascending to confront Nāmakaokapāo'o underscore themes of bravery and challenge, echoing the Hawaiian martial ethos of *kāne*, often symbolizing valor and prowess.
• The reference to Puali'i, whose name breaks down into Puali—*loose, weak* or *free*, and 'ī—*to go, to self*, possibly indicating a lineage or symbolic figure—further emphasizing themes of kinship, rivalry, or rebellion.
• The confrontation amplifies themes of youth, valor, and familial conflict through the mention of Puali'i as the slain father of the protagonist, Nāmakaokapāo'o, aligning with recurrent motifs in Hawaiian legends where personal and familial loyalty intertwine with heroic quests.
• Overall, the passage reflects a layered narrative involving ancestral spirits, heroic challenge, and the importance of lineage and kinship—core elements in Hawaiian oral tradition and storytelling.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
